greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: a(n), when spelled in English, is the smallest positive integer with exactly n letters.
comment: In this version 101 is written "one hundred one", etc.

This uses the conventions that "and" is never used and two-digit numbers are not used before "hundred". The sequence is labeled "finite" because there is no widely accepted naming convention for arbitrarily large numbers. - _David Wasserman_, Dec 20 2004
link: Hans Havermann, Table of n, a(n) for n = 3..758
Hans Havermann, Growth illustration for this sequence
example: The 3rd term has 5 letters; the smallest positive integer with this number of letters is 3 (three).
xref: Cf. A001166, A052196 (the 'largest' analog of this sequence), A084390.
results.author: Peter Kolbus (peter(AT)kolbusfamily.com), Mar 11 2003
